newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK pro-democracy supporters ponder China response.
newsitem.headline: HK pro-democracy supporters ponder China response.

text.p: Some of Hong Kong's pro-democracy activists voiced concern on Saturday that their campaign might provoke a Chinese response when Beijing regains control of this British colony in less than three days.
"I am worried about our slogan 'Topple one-party rule'," said a participant in a public forum held by the Alliance in Support of the Patriotic Democratic Movement in China.
"How will the Beijing government treat us after the handover? What will they do to us?" she asked.
More than 100 people packed a fenced-off pedestrian area, surrounded by political cartoons and other mementos from Hong Kong's democratic movement.
"The pro-democracy movement in China in 1989 resulted in mass killing. Do we want to see more people massacred in Hong Kong?", another participant asked.
The British Union Jack will be lowered at midnight on June 30 and China's red flag will rise, symbolising a new era under Communist rule.
"The democratic movements are not stirred by just several activists, but the majority of the people...We can neither stop them nor rush them," said Szeto Wah, the Alliance leader.
"Some say we can get what we want if we kowtow to the Chinese authorities, but we will end up letting them dictate our every move," Wong Yuk Man, editor of the Mad Dog Daily, said to loud applause.
Other participants expressed concern over self-censorship among the local media.
"The media seem to be emphasising celebrations and ignoring the dissenting voices," said another participant.
Szeto, a prominent member of the pro-democracy movement, said this was because Beijing has many subtle ways to censor the local newspapers.
He said this included withholding advertising or blocking their investments in mainland China.
"China is a shark, we are just a shrimp," he said. "But we are a poisonous shrimp, and if the shark swallows us it will vomit to death."
